dialogues.speaker: IN AN INTERVIEW ROOM.
dialogues.text: Several 50 inch WIDESCREEN MONITORS are mounted on the wa creating a collage of ABSTRACT MOTION on their screens. THE REAL ABBEY TYLER sits in a chair, the camera frames h from the waist up. She is a thirty-eight year old female with a good deal of pain evident in her eyes. She's rail thin, edges of bones pushing out her skin like needles under tissue paper. The left corner of her mouth twitches cccasionally as she looks to the right of camera, where the interviewer sits.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Please state your name for the camera.

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: Doctor Abigail Elizabeth Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: Have you provided us with Che master tapes from your archive?

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: Yes I have.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: Is everything you are about to tell me as close to factual as possible?

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: {nods) Yes, yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Are you willing to submit to a lie detector test to confirm these answers?

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: CLATUNDE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Thank you...So, where would you like to begin? ©

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Tyler frowns.

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: I guess uh...after what happened with Will--my husband. I uh...went to my friend...who's also a psychiatrist--Dr.{ NAME WITHHELD, ALIAS--ABEL CAMPOS] because I was having trouble dealing with how he... (starts to get emotional} How it happened...and who did it...

dialogues.speaker: LOCATION
dialogues.text: Over black, a poor AUDIO RECORDING is heard, as SUBTITLES follow the dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: L'il _be fine.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: 7 int $ ‘

dialogues.speaker: IN DR. ABEL CAMPOS' OFFICE.
dialogues.text: Daylight floods the room, warming dark wooden furniture. Seated to the left is ABBEY TYLER, 36, a widow whose suff has permeated her every being. TITLE: (CAST MEMBER) as ABBEY TYLER Across from her is DR. ABEL CAMPOS, 50, a psychiatrist wh disposition is relaxed, composed, and comforting. On a table between them a portable TAPE RECORDER records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Yeah. Campos gets up, aims a VHS CAMERA at Abbey, and hits RECO

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: RECORDED: 10-1-00 9:36am

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: (light hearted) Counseling another psychiatrist is like talking to myself. The REAL DR. TYLER lies further back in her chair and tak a calming breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: Dr. Abbey Tyler Campos stands over her and extends a finger.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS, (C.S.)
dialogues.text: Watch my finger as I count back...20, 19, 18, 17... Abbey's eyes roll up as she follows his finger over her h Then slowly, her eyes close. Campos sits down out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: (gently) Abbey, lets go back to the night of September 9th of this year.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: What was the weather like?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Warm...warmer than normal...even though it was snowing outside.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Now...let's go to when you were with Will -- just before the intruder entered your room.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Describe what you see. Abbey's eyes are working hard beneath her eye lids, flick back and forth. Then her face relaxes and a smile parts h lips.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: We're making love...it was wonderful kind, gentle...

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN LEFT FRAME OF SPLIT/SCREEN
dialogues.text: ABBEY'S P.O.V. as she leans down and kisses WILL, 35, a m in love with the woman above him. He gently caresses her cheek as they make love.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: ...then we fell asleep.... IN RIGHT FRAME: ABBEY'S NECK goes limp, and her head fal to the side. e@

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's quiet a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: What do you remember next?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: We're awake...both of us...wide awake. ..-And we're...lying here...

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: What woke you up?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: I don't...Nothing...we were just...lying here...

dialogues.speaker: IN LEFT FRAME
dialogues.text: next to Will. His eyes are open, darting back and forth a they study her... A shadow falls over Will's face, and then

dialogues.speaker: METAL SLAMS DOWN
dialogues.text: into his

dialogues.speaker: CHEST,
dialogues.text: BLASTING into his SKIN as BLCOD EXPLODES UPWARDS. Abbey breaths in sharply and pulls back in SHOCK. She loo up at the INTRUDER -- and FLINCHES back and

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT FRAME NOW FILLS ENTIRE SCREEN
dialogues.text: Abbey SHRIEKS at the top of her lungs and covers her face with her arms

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Someone stabbed him! In the chest! Oh my G--!

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Abbey! Stay with me! Stay with me! What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: I don't know! I--it's too much! It's moving so fast, but it feels like we're frozen-- I can't see it!

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Shhhh. Abbey relax! Calm down, Try and see the face!

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Oh my God not again. I can't--I can't see it! PLEASE STOP! PLEASE

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: STOP-!! IT'S TOO MUCH! IT‘S TOO

dialogues.speaker: MUCH
dialogues.text: Dr. Campos tries to regain control, counts her back out o hypnosis as she wails uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: eS --Focus on my voice--

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: -Focus on my voice, you will be fully awakened and conscious in 5,4,3,2,1... Abbey breaks hypnosis, sits up, doesn't remember crying, wipes tears, sits a moment silently, awkwardly, before bu her face in her hands and crying. Campos puts an arm around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Abbey... She cries for a little bit longer and then wipes her eyes

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: If I could just see his face we could...I--feel so...He was killed and I was right there--and I--I-- can't described who did it...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's natural to feel guilt...it's just as unnatural to feel it was your fault. She wipes her face again.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (whispers) I can't help it.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: You said something there...you said 'It's too much.’ What did you mean by that? Abbey thinks a moment...and then slowly shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: «..I don't know....

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: It feels like maybe it's...something we should keep an eye on. Campos holds her hands in a very paternal way, trying to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: You should consider taking some time off -- real time. That two weeks didn't count. It may help you find clarity with what happened--

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: I want to finish the study.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Which is exactly what I knew you'd say. Which is what you always say when confronted with the notion of spending time away from work. Uncle Sam isn't exactly beating down your door for a return on his investment. Abbey shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: It meant a lot to Will. He would of wanted me to finish it as soon as I could. Off Campos' lock --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: @ I'll be OK. She stands up abruptly lifting her face out of frame, wip stray tears, attempting to pull it together

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: I know you wouldn't, but please don't tell anyone about our sessions. (small smile) Wouldn't be good for my practice.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: TIMECODE
dialogues.text: He reaches towards the camera, pulls the tape out and han it to her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: A RED CESNA
dialogues.text: SOARS HIGH above the SNOW COVERED world of Alaska, cuttin @ hard to the left as it ROARS across the afternoon sky.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Abbey flies the plane, her face is a little more composed Flying is the best therapy of all. A family picture of Will and her two children Ronnie and Ashley decorates the dashboard. FADE IN TEXT -- 'THE VOICE OF DR. TYLER‘

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I flew, I felt at peace. It was just me, the wind and the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: THE CESNA
dialogues.text: straightens out and FLIES over SNOW COVERED MOUNTAINS -- their rolling hills of white ar blindingly beautiful. THE REAL DR. TYLER (V.O. I think Alaskans are lucky in that way--that flying is one of the only ways to get around the state.  10 The plane SOARS UP and over another MOUNTAIN RANGE, revea a town nestled next to the sparkling waters of the ARCTIC and the MONSTROUS blue-white ice of a GLACIER behind it. This is a town on the edge of the wild.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT.
dialogues.text: Abbey is smiling. CONTROL TOWER (radio) Welcome Ten-twenty-three, you've got some Clear air turbulence ahead, some cross winds, descend to one- fifty, hold at altitude.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (to mic) Thanks--descending to one-fifty and holding, ten-twenty-three. Abbey throttles down and the plane begins its descent.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE NOME
dialogues.text: the AIRPORT RUNWAY comes into view as 1923 glides towards it, passing over the warehouse style buildings and two la roadways cf Nome.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT.
dialogues.text: CONTROL TOWER (radio) Ten-twenty-three you're clear to land.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Ten-twenty-three's landing -- have a good day Ori. ORI (radio) You too Abbey, thank you. She pulls hard to the left,

dialogues.speaker: BANKING THE PLANE
dialogues.text: almost sideways in a fighter jet like maneuver. The wing flaps straighten out, straightening out the plane as

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: the RUNWAY lines up directly with the front of the windsh Abbey throttles down further and tilts the nose up as the

dialogues.speaker: GROUND RUSHES
dialogues.text: il up to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY'S VCLVO ROARS
dialogues.text: down Ahkovak Street. Snow covered barrack type buildings dominate both sides of the road. She turns left

dialogues.speaker: ONTO APAYAUK STREET,
dialogues.text: heading south as snow falls.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE TYLER'S HEALTH
dialogues.text: Abbey's car pulls into the driveway of a Victorian styled building, passing a SIGN: TYLER'S HEALTH & CARE.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LOBBY
dialogues.text: Abbey strides in fully composed and collected. She passes by her secretary's desk, where THERESA[ALIAS], 50's, a da haired woman with beauty rarely seen at her age, types on computer.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Any messages?

dialogues.speaker: THERESA
dialogues.text: No, but Scott's waiting in your office, and you have a four and a five o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (nods) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: THERESA
dialogues.text: How was it coming in?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Bumpy. You'd think as beautiful as that sky was, the air could never be that rough.

dialogues.speaker: THERESA
dialogues.text: The stuff that really shakes us, we seldom ever see coming. Abbey kind of smiles at that, what it means, how matter-o factly it was uttered. She walks down a hallway and into

dialogues.speaker: HER OFFICE
dialogues.text: 12 to find SCOTT STRACINSKY[ALIAS], 41 -- Troubled. Tense. Sleepless circles are carved beneath his eyes. TITLE: (CAST MEMBER) as SCOTT STRACINSKY Abbey beams, greets him warmly.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: How you doing Scott?

dialogues.speaker: SCOTT
dialogues.text: Alright. She closes the door and sets her stuff down on her desk. Wooden panelled bookshelves line three of the walls, and fourth a wall of windows featuring a vast snowscape outsi A deep leather couch flanked by two plush chairs are at t center of the room, her desk is off to the side. This is office of comfort, of trust. One feels at ease within the walis.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Make yourself comfortable. They sit on the chairs directly across from each other. O the coffee table she pushes eject on her tape recorder an inserts a tape labeled: SCOTT STRACINSKY

dialogues.speaker: THE SUN
dialogues.text: is almost below the snowed horizon as Abkey's VCLVO pulls in front of a series of COZY BUNGALOWS known as NOME ELEMENTARY SCHOCL. SCHOOL CHILDREN meander about, walking home or waiting fo their rides. IN NOME ELEMENTARY SCHOOL -- LOBBY.  16 ASHLEY TYLER, 6, the cutest, saddest, little girl you've ever seen, sits on a bench looking straight ahead, not se the children as they pass by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to her rests a long white walking stick. This child blind. RALPH[ALIAS] (6} runs up to Ashley and makes all kinds of faces at her. She whips up her stick and just misses his face.

dialogues.speaker: RALPH
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Knock it off. He sticks out his tongue one more time and runs off.

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I felt so sorry for my baby...and I feel...responsible...it's not a phenomenon that a lot of people understand and we've had to make quite an adjustment.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT TEXT
dialogues.text: Abbey enters the LOBBY and walks over to her. She looks a her daughter with sad eyes, but she keeps it from her voi

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Hi sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Hi mommy.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Abbey takes her hand and she stands up. They walk out

dialogues.speaker: ONTO THE STREET
dialogues.text: and towards her car, Abbey leading the way.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: How was school?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: on. ®

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? OK? Did something happen? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Ralph called me a 'faker'.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: A what? A "faker?"

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: He said I could see before and now I was just pretending. He said I just wanted everybody to feel sorry for me because of Daddy. Abbey blanches, hates hearing this kind of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Wasn't Ralph the kid your friends caught eating his own boogers? This makes Ashley smile.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Then why are we worried about what Ralph's saying. Ralph's got his own problems.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah mommy.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (pends to tickle her) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ASHLET
dialogues.text: (squirming)

dialogues.speaker: YEAH
dialogues.text: Abbey picks her tiny body up in to her arms and spins her around. The two girls laugh as they get in and Abbey star the car up.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE ABBEY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: It's a two story house situated up on a hill that looks l it's right out of a storybook. Snow falls lightly as the Volvo pulls up into the drivewa all of Nome can be seen behind it.  18

dialogues.speaker: IN ABBEY'S KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Ashley sits at the kitchen table listening to the Discove Channel on TV. She passes her hand back and forth in fron of her eyes, trying to see it. Abbey cooks soup and meat loaf behind her.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Mom?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Yes sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: When's dinner gonna be ready?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: How soon?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Real soon. The kitchen door opens and RONNIE[ALIAS], 15, walks insid his boots caked in snow. He's tall for his age, has an athletic build and a huge chip on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Hi darling.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: (mutters) Hey. Abbey glances over at him.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Your boots. He sighs, takes them off, throws them next to the door, a walks cff into the living room. Abbey watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: IN ABBEY'S DINNING ROOM
dialogues.text: the three of them sit at the dinning room table in prayer Abbey and Ashley's heads are bowed, Ronnie's is not, and eyes are open.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Lord, thank you for everything we have. Please continue to bless our family. Please help Ashley overcome her loss of sight, help her see again like she did. Thank you, in Jesus! name we pray, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Amen. They begin eating in awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: {to Ronnie) How was school?

dialogues.speaker: RONNTE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It was alright.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Learn anything new?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: No. The silence ccntinues for awhile. Ashley cocks her ear ba and forth between the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (to Ronnie) What time's your game tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Who you playing?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: I told you already, Browerville.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: Dad never forgot. That comment stings Abbey.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Well...your dad's not here.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: No...he's not. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looking up, glowering) Can you accept it yet?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Accept what?

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: (like stone) ..-what happened to dad. Abbey absently grabs a platter of food.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Not in front of your sister.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Nothing honey.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You're never gonna face it are you?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Stop it.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Face what? Ronnie turns to Ashley, seems to forget she’s only six.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: How dad died. Ashley gasps.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Damn it Ronnie! What's wrong with you? Ronnie pushes himself back from the table.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: You go around helping other people with their problems--

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: --stop it! stop it!--

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: --and you can't even help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: --What the hell is that supposed to mean--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie walks out.

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE
dialogues.text: --Or your kids... Somewhere in the house, a door slams.

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Mommy...? What did--what does he mean...? No answer...

dialogues.speaker: ASHLEY
dialogues.text: Mommy... ? Unable to answer Abbey looks at her angelic face...at innocence only a child can demonstrate.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE OF ABBEY'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: the night is complete. An OWL perched on a branch watches through the windows as lights are turned off. All is stil FADE IN TEXT -- 'THE VOICE OF DR. TYLER’

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: You know...he was right. Not only could I not help myself, I couldn't help him either.

dialogues.speaker: IN ABBEY'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: she turns off the lights and walks down the

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: to ASHLEY'S BEDROOM DOOR. She peeks in and sees Ashley lying in bed. The love is obvious on her face. She continues

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: to Ronnie's recom. The door is cracked and she peeks INSIDE. He's lying in bed as well, the lights are off. She stares unsure what to do about him, then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I realized that...for the first time as a mother, I became the enemy. I represented to him everything that was bad in life, and I also represented failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ronnie opens his eyes as his mother walks away, then slow closes them again.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY WALKS BY
dialogues.text: another door, hesitates, then goes back and opens it. IN THE STUDY. Abbey turns the lights on revealing a rather large room w two desks and books everywhere. She walks over to Will's desk which is covered by papers, folders and books in an orderly fashion -- it's as if it were still in use. Father comits murder-suicide By Kate Ripple Fairbanks Daity News Nome, Alaska - Tommy Fisher murdered bis wife and two children before committing suicide yesterday night at approximately 3:30 AM, following several hours of hostage neg- atiations. There are more unsclved murders and missing people in Nome than any other city in Alaska-- three years of which have been under your watch! Whatever is happening in this town is real, is dangerous, and must be dealt with!

Whatever governmental study you're conducting, whatever you and your husband were after, is bringing nothing but bad things to a town that's had enough. Now if I decided to press, I could make you an accessory to a multiple homicide. I don't want that...just like I don't want whatever you're doing to continue. So, in fairness, let this be understood...you've been warned.

I don't think that five people slain in a little over three weeks can be chalked up to simple coincidence-- especially in a town that has a history of death and disappearance. dialogues.text: And what about Ashley?

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) She...I had to recover from that night...took me a couple days to wake up--and as you know I-I was changed forever. August couldn't bring me into the station so he...he came to me. She looks down at the table...not wanting to say these ne few words.

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: ...he talked to me about Ashley...and about Will.

dialogues.speaker: IN A NOME HOSPITAL ROOM.
dialogues.text: Abbey sits in bed...her back against the headboard...her hair stringy, moist, unkempt. She's lost too much weight...bone is pressing against her skin...an empty she of a once strong, healthy woman. Her body is very still, unmoving. August sits in a chair next to her, a MANILA FOLDER in ha

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: I hate to ask you these questions-- now, while you're in this condition your in--but this is one of those things in life that can't wait. Abbey nods weakly, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: Abbey. What happened to your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (quietly, weakly) I told you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you told me and what actually happened are two different things.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: No--they're the same.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: OK...you want to play this game?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: It's not a game-~

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: How did Will die? She hesitates, pulls back-~stunned by the question.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: C'mon....Answer it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: He was murdered.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: No Abbey. What you're telling me and what happened are two different things. Now one more time: How did Will die? Her eyes are darting around...she's breathing harder...he skin is losing it's color...panic is welling in her throa

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: Why are you asking me this?

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: (yells) Campos! Get in here! A deputy opens the door and Campos walks in, circles to t other side of the bed and kneels next to Abbey.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Tr's OK...1t's OK...

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: No it's not OK. We're getting to the bottom of everything now. Again: How did your husband die?

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: I teld you, an intruder entered our house and killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 107 August and Campos exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: He's going to show you something that will upset you. But it has to be done, understand? She doesn't understand. With what strength she has left, she looks at Campos hard. August opens his file...and holds up a PHOTO for her to see... She gasps--half SCREAMS, doesn't have the strength to scr again--her face is a perfect mask of revulsion, of tears...anguish.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: -why...? THE PHOTC is of WILL TYLER--with a BLOODY HOLE in the sid of his head the size of a GRAPEFRUIT.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: This is the head of a man-- He holds up a SECOND PHOTO, this one of a 9mm PISTOL.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: --who used this gun, to blow his own brains out. Abbey can't stop sobbing--her eyes are closed, her head t away--whimpering. Campos is caressing her face, almost protecting it from the photos.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... August shakes the photos for emphasis.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: This is how you do it--and he did it right. Suicide Abbey. That's how your husband died.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: He took a pistol and shot himself in the head--there was no knife, no der--just him and his own gun edge of your bed. int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --he's not that man--he wouldn't do that to us, to his family--

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: --I've seen it before, I'll see it again--

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (to Campos) Tell him...tell him he's wrong. I would have known he was gonna--I'm a psychiatrist---Christ----I would have known--! Campos holds her close, trying to comfort her.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: You can't blame yourself for what was going on in his head. Who knows what he learned, what he didn't share...what finally broke him--

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: No...no...

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Sometimes the closest signs, the ones closest to us, are the hardest to read.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: (to Abbey) Now you know the reality. August puts the photos down...and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: And for the last time. Tell me what happened to Ashley. She can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: You have to tell him...for Ashley. Tears wetting her cheeks, she pulls away from Campos and looks at him...softly.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: You know what happened. You experienced it. Except we came back...she didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campos! eyes lock on hers...and then they give in, looki down to the bed. He can't refute her words...not after wh he's seen. Not after what they've been through.

dialogues.speaker: ABBEY
dialogues.text: (to August) I swear to you--I swear it. She was taken, by-by something. ..something not from here....... I swear it.... August looks between the two of them, his face like a bul ready to charge--but unsure which bulls eye to hit first.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: (then quietly) It's difficult to go back. He arranges the pictures and closes the files just so.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPOS
dialogues.text: Go back? August takes his time, doesn't rush it.

dialogues.speaker: AUGUST
dialogues.text: Back over the line, from fiction to reality. You can't just stop being insane whenever you want to. It's @ the kind of thing that stays with you forever.

dialogues.speaker: THE INTERVIEW ROOM.
dialogues.text: Abbey is quiet...lost in the memory.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: So Will committed suicide? ...the kind of thing one would not want to admit...would want to say out loud...but she does--

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: -yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: Your credibility....How do ycu expect me-- the audience-- to believe anything you have to say, after you were hallucinating the murder of your husband?

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: ~ They weren't hallucinations--I just @ couldn't--it can be difficult to (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: face the truth, and with Will, that's how I dealt with it. And .no matter what you believe, the recordings do not jie You can doubt my words-- you would doubt me even if I were a saint, I mean we're talking about things that--that aren't normal--but what you cannot doubt are the recordings--t-the other people--their stories. [name removed] is dead [mame removed] back is broken-- a- and Ashley...she's still gone. These are hard facts.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: They appear to be--

dialogues.speaker: THE REAL DR. TYLER
dialogues.text: (twitches) i THEY ARE. You can sit there and speculate but I have to keep hope alive...I have to believe in what were doing--this film--my story~--that it will help. TI have to believe she's still alive somewhere, that she's safe...that there's a chance I'm going to see her again-- > hold her again-- @ (starts to cry) * --hear her voice...I--I just want my little girl back! She's all I have. I can't bring back Will, Ronnie he-- he--he--blames me for everything--he shut me out of kis life! Mothers shouldn't be alone. We shouldn't be without our children... (desperate) I just want my baby back...I just want her back... Tears glisten off her cheeks as her face continues to twi but she's somehow holding it together, somehow preventing the complete emotional collapse you'd expect.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: I think we can stop here. The camera's slowly zcom out in farewell...and for the fi time we see that Dr. Tyler is in a WHEELCHAIR with ARMS a LEGS so WITHERED away, they don't look like they've moved years...

dialogues.speaker: STILL IMAGES
dialogues.text: of the TYLER FAMILY dance across the screen.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: With no credible evidence, kidnapping charges against Dr. Tyler were dropped. Her daughter Ashley has not been found. An image of ASHLEY SMILING zooms towards us, it morphs in an OLDER VERSION of her -- approximately 7 years older.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: If you have any information about Ashley Tyler that may assist local authorities please call toll-free 1- 800-MISSING.

dialogues.speaker: ON A HILL OVERLOOKING NOME,
dialogues.text: Olatunde stands, looking directly at us.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: Someone else is interested in Nome as well. Since the 1960's, there have been over 2,000 visits to Nome by the Federal Bureau of Investigation -- the highest in Alaska. Second is Anchorage, with a population 76 times larger than Nome. The FBI has paid them only 353 visits. The camera begins craning back, bidding us adieu.

dialogues.speaker: OLATUNDE
dialogues.text: In the end...what you believe, is yours to decide.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: Psychiatrist released from custody, child not found. By Kate Ripple Fairbanks Daily News Nome, Alaska ~ The only susp- j ect in the disappearance of 5 year old Ashley Tyler was teleased fr- | om custody yesterday, with all c- harges dropped after spending 2 montis under house arrest for her daughters disappearance on the m-- oming of October 10". “We’ ve got nothing on her, and we haven’t found the girl,” chief Moates said. Asked. if he believ- ed Dr, Tyler was.guilty, he stopp- éd short of saying she was innoce- nt, “There's #6 motive, no evide- “nce, ahd no girl. On paper there's no reason she should have kidnap- ped her own daughter. But she’s nat here, and we have no idea w- here the hell she is.” Reports speculate that Ashley's | disappearance could be related to; the hundreds of people who have disappeared in the city, which has cases going back to 1960 and occ- urting as recently as last month. Most of Nome’s missing person cases have gone unsolved, as have most missing person cases throug- hout Alaska due to the severity of the land.
